Description: A hollow terracotta seated naked woman, a beneficent demon, with hands raised in blessing and protection. She wears an oval pendant between her breasts, bracelets and anklets. The head is possibly alien, but comes from a comparable figure, and one close in fabric, both in body and surface appearance. Her hair is elaborately dressed, with braids and loops, and is pulled into a circular bun at the rear. The ears are pierced from front to rear. Summary treatment of the body at the back. Left forearm and hand are lost; the head joined to the body by plaster. A hole is bored underneath, perhaps a firing-vent (there is no other), but enlarged and adapted for a peg on a modern base. Two-piece mould. Body: micaceous brown Nile silt with a grey-brown core and a dark-brown surface. Head: brown Nile silt, with some mica; dark-brown surface.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Ekhmim (Akhmim) or Elephantine are possible sources. Roman, late first century or second century AD. Comparanda: Near: Breccia 1934: no. 198; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 113; Petrie 1905: pl. l:105 (head lost), from House K at Herakleopolis Magna, dated third century AD (Petrie and Currelly 1905: 26–7; my date, p. 4: second to fifth century AD); Petrie Museum uc34344, from Hawara; Pingiatoglou 1993: no. 269 (head lost), dated second half of second century AD; Pons Mellado 1998: 112, 1981/1/203;.Skupinska-Løvset 1978: no. UT 142, dated second half of second century AD; Török 1995: nos. 170 and 171. Breccia 1934: no. 230 is very near, but is apparently male.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3115)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
